A Fox and Number Game:

solution 1 : for every pair of numbers, if we keep subtracting one from another till they are equal then we'll reach their greatest common divisor. ex: 12, 8 -> 4, 8 -> 4, 4 ex: 5, 15 -> 5, 10 -> 5, 5 so we'll find the greatest common divisor of all the numbers and the final array will be composed of this number.

solution 2: we can just simulate the process, while (there are two number not equal) subtract one from another.

C Vasya and Football

we'll store the names of the player who got a yellow card and who got a red card, and at each event: - if the player is already out then ignore this event - if it's a red card then the palyer is out - if it's the first yellow for the player then store that he got a yellow - if it's the second yellow for the player then the player is out

D Valuable Resources

Lets first solve the 1D version of this problem. if want to choose the minimum length line segment that covers all the mines, we'll just use the segment from the mine of min x to the mine of max x. now for the two dimensional version, the width and height of the mine are independed, so we'll find the min width and min height since we want a square not a rectangle then the side length will be the max of the width and height take care of integer overflow

code http://pastebin.com/e7zxifKk

E Fence

for each index idx we want to find the sum from idx to idx + k — we can do this in O(1) by accumulating the sum. we'll have an array where arr[i] is the sum from i to the end of the array, then arr[i] — arr[i+k] discards the sum from i+k to the end leaving us with the required sum so we'll first form that array by accumulating the sum (for i n -> 1 arr[i] += arr[i+1]) then we'll pick the index with the minimum sum

code http://pastebin.com/ADzEy95g

F New Year Book Reading

first lets make some observations to find the initial order of the stack. Assume the first book we'll read was in any position other than the top of the stack. So what will do is pay some cost to lift some books that were over it then place it on top of the stack so whatever position the book was, it'll return to the top of the stack, so the optimal thing to do is to place it there and not pay any cost. now for the second book we read, we know for sure that we'll read the first book first so it'll be in the top of the stack and we'll pay some cost to lift it. and after lifting the first book, we'll lift all the other books on top of the second and pay additional cost and at the end we'll place it on the top of stack so the optimal place for the second book is right under the first, because no matter its position it'll just end up on the top after we read it
